fr.xebia.cascading.learn.level3

Class Reducing

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.xebia.cascading.learn.level3.Reducing

  • public class Reducing
extends java.lang.Object
    Once each input has been individually curated, it can be needed to aggregate information.

      static cascading.flow.FlowDef aggregate(cascading.tap.Tap<?,?,?> source, cascading.tap.Tap<?,?,?> sink)

      static cascading.flow.FlowDef efficientlyAggregate(cascading.tap.Tap<?,?,?> source, cascading.tap.Tap<?,?,?> sink)
      Aggregation should be done as soon as possible and Cascading does have a technique almost similar to map/reduce 'combiner'.

    • Method Detail

      • aggregate

        public static cascading.flow.FlowDef aggregate(cascading.tap.Tap<?,?,?> source,
                               cascading.tap.Tap<?,?,?> sink)
        GroupBy "word" and then apply Count. It should be noted that once grouped, the semantic is different. You will need to use a Every instead of a Each. And Count is an Aggregator instead of a Function. source field(s) : "word" sink field(s) : "word","count"
        See Also:
        http://docs.cascading.org/cascading/2.5/userguide/html/ch03s03.html

      • efficientlyAggregate

        public static cascading.flow.FlowDef efficientlyAggregate(cascading.tap.Tap<?,?,?> source,
                                          cascading.tap.Tap<?,?,?> sink)
        Aggregation should be done as soon as possible and Cascading does have a technique almost similar to map/reduce 'combiner'. Use CountBy in order to do the same thing as above. It is shorter to write and more efficient. source field(s) : "word" sink field(s) : "word","count"
        See Also:
        http://docs.cascading.org/cascading/2.5/userguide/html/ch08s08.html
